content: Whiteboard Friday - Spring Break and Strike Fighters Whiteboard Friday By: Darren Slatten January 22, 2009 This YouMoz entry was submitted by one of our community members. The author’s views are entirely their own (excluding an unlikely case of hypnosis) and may not reflect the views of Moz. Table of Contents Copied! By: Darren Slatten January 22, 2009 Whiteboard Friday - Spring Break and Strike Fighters Whiteboard Friday This YouMoz entry was submitted by one of our community members. The author’s views are entirely their own (excluding an unlikely case of hypnosis) and may not reflect the views of Moz. Hey everyone. I've been getting a ton of emails lately from SEOmoz members (and Rebecca) who keep telling me that I should post YOUmoz entries more often. They tell me that they miss my unique writing style, my sense of humor, and above all, my world's best SEO advice. So even though I'm very busy playing with Legos and growing a beard, I suppose I can work a YOUmoz post into my hectic schedule. But before I begin, I just want to make one thing perfectly clear: No one really emailed me--I just made all that up, because I couldn't think of a better introductory paragraph. Still with me? Good. During last week's Whiteboard Friday (SEO for Video Content), Rand talked about video content issues, such as how to get it indexed and ranked. One of the tips he mentioned for indexing is to create a text version (i.e., transcription) of the video's dialogue and include it on the page where the video is embedded. This text version provides search engines (and the hearing-impaired) with the same content that would otherwise be inaccessible. This tip brought up a couple of questions: What services can I use to transcribe my videos? What automated transcription programs are available? I did a bit of research on this topic, and I'd like to share my findings--not because they're incredibly helpful, but because they're entertaining. For transcription services, I found out that Google actually has a page that lists transcription companies which support Google Video. I also found a page that explains how to submit a transcript directly to Google Video. But if you're antisocial like me, you're gonna want an automated solution, so you can transcribe your videos without the hassle of talking to any humans. My search for said human-free solutions led me to this excellent video tutorial, which showed me how to use Adobe Premiere Pro CS4 to transcribe videos into text. What I really liked about this solution is that I already own this software. So I decided to test it out... by transcribing Rand's Whiteboard Friday video! First, I downloaded the original video in Quicktime format from Vimeo.com. Then, I opened the file in Premiere Pro and followed the basic instructions from that tutorial I linked to. I chose the high-quality output option, and out of curiosity I enabled the "Identify Speakers" option. The video tutorial says the average video-to-text conversion takes about 3 times as long as the original video, but my computer transcribed Rand's 6m:53s video in 5m:48s!? (Probably because I'm using an insanely-fast custom PC.) Anyways, here is the result. I haven't edited it whatsoever--so yes, it really did recognize Rand as like 6 different speakers, and it really does recognize/capitalize all the obscure proper nouns like "YouTube," "Spike TV," and "Strike Fighter." I recommend you open the Whiteboard Friday video in a separate tab and try to read along as it plays in the background. Good luck!
